Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Gabriela Jaramillo is "Defects and inhomogeneities in pattern forming systems." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Arizona, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Shankar Venkataramani.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to understand how defects, or impurities, create or modify patterns in spatially extended systems. Here a defect is anything that changes the properties of the system in a localized region. The examples considered were oscillating chemical reactions, arrays of oscillators with nonlocal coupling, and the phenomenon of Rayleigh-Benard convection.

The first two are examples of oscillatory media, which can support target patterns and spiral waves, while the last example gives rise to striped patterns in the form of convection rolls. To model these phenomena we used amplitude equations which, in contrast to models derived from first principles, capture the essential qualitative behavior of a pattern without being overly complicated. In this context, defects can be modeled as perturbations to these equations. Therefore, the solutions that emerge after this perturbation is introduced give a description of how the defect generates or modifies the pattern. With this approach we obtained the following results.

i) Defects in convection rolls modify the wavenumber (a measure of the spacing between rolls/stripes) and shift the striped pattern by a constant value. The magnitude of the change in wavenumber and shift depend on both the location of the impurity and the average wavenumber of the system. It was also shown that for select locations there is no change in wavenumber.

ii) In arrays of oscillators a defect corresponds to a patch of oscillators with a different frequency than the rest of the group. In the case of an array of oscillators with nonlocal coupling and distributed over the 2-d plane, defects can generate target patterns provided the patch of oscillators has a lower frequency. 

Visually target patterns look like a series of concentric waves that propagate away from the defect. The wavenumber and frequency of these waves depends on the mass of the impurity. One of the main challenges of this problem is that the relation between the wavenumber of the pattern and the mass of the inhomogeneity does not follow from a regular perturbation argument. In fact, if the mass of the inhomogeneity is of order epsilon, then the wavenumber is smaller than epsilon raised to any power. In this project a formula describing this relation was established. On the other hand, the results show that if the impurity represents a patch of oscillators with a higher frequency, then target patterns do not form.

iii) On going project: In oscillating chemical reactions moving impurities can create distinct patterns depending on their speed, c.  There is a critical value, c*, that signals a change in the resulting pattern and which depends on the size of the impurity. For small speeds such that c < c*, the pattern initially looks like a sheared target pattern. However, because the waves generated by the impurity travel faster than the speed at which the impurity moves, the newly generated waves interact with existing waves and destroy this initial configuration. On the other hand for large speeds such that  c*< c, the impurity moves faster than any generated wave and the pattern has a parabolic shape.

Broader Impacts: The PI was co-organizer of the Math Teachers Circle at the University of Arizona from the Fall of 2016 until the Spring of 2018. The Teachers Circle aims at providing high school, middle school, and elementary school teachers with the opportunity to connect with coworkers and mathematicians and practice their problem solving skills. The PI's role as organizer was to recruit faculty from the math department and industry to lead these sessions, as well as to provide feedback and guidance to these volunteers regarding topics and problems for these workshops.
